title: 111_s3957
content: The "Graduate Medical Education Reform Act of 2010" includes provisions for Medicare indirect medical education performance adjustment, primary care training bonus, payments for graduate medical education to hospitals, transparency in graduate medical education, establishment of a trust fund, and financing the trust fund from fees on health plans. The Social Security Act is amended to include an adjustment for hospital performance based on health care workforce priorities specified by the Secretary. The Secretary shall specify health care workforce priorities, including training in primary care, various settings, patient care coordination, cost and value of treatment options, interprofessional care teams, system error identification, and health information use. The Secretary specifies health care workforce priorities, including training in primary care, patient care coordination, cost of treatment options, interprofessional care teams, system error identification, and health information technology. Measures developed must be endorsed by consensus organizations and involve a consensus-based process. The Secretary will publish a proposed set of measures by January 1, 2013, for public comment, and a final set of measures by June 30, 2013, to be used for adjusting payments to hospitals. Adjustments may be made to hospital payments under this clause, not exceeding 3 percent of the total amount. The Secretary will ensure budget neutrality in these adjustments, making sure total payments to hospitals remain the same as if the clause had not been enacted. 'Primary care' in this clause refers to family medicine and general practice. The term 'primary care' includes family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics, preventive medicine, obstetrics and gynecology, and psychiatry. Bonus payments for training in primary care are provided to hospitals during a 12-month applicable period starting on July 1 each year. Hospitals may receive bonus payments from the Medical Education Trust Fund if at least 33% of full-time equivalent residents in their medical residency training programs are enrolled in primary care. Total payments to eligible hospitals for this purpose are capped for each applicable period. The bonus payments from the Medical Education Trust Fund to hospitals are capped for each applicable period based on the funds appropriated for that fiscal year. SEC. 3. Payments for graduate medical education to hospitals not eligible under the Medicare program are addressed in a new section added to Title XVIII of the Social Security Act. The Secretary will establish a program for payments to eligible hospitals for medical residency training programs, funded by the Medical Education Trust Fund. The program for payments to eligible hospitals for medical residency training programs is funded by the Medical Education Trust Fund. Eligible hospitals are defined as children's hospitals and freestanding psychiatric hospitals. Total payments to eligible hospitals in an applicable period are limited by the funds appropriated to the Trust Fund for that fiscal year. Eligible hospitals for medical residency training programs include children's hospitals and freestanding psychiatric hospitals meeting specific criteria such as having a high percentage of under 18 inpatients, a Medicare provider number, and an accredited residency program. Additionally, hospitals with a minimum of 3,000 annual births and low Medicare discharges are also eligible for payments from the Medical Education Trust Fund. The curr_chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for hospitals to participate in medical residency training programs under Medicare, including having a Medicare provider number and an accredited residency program. The term "applicable period" is defined in relation to another section. The Secretary is required to create regulations for implementing this section. Increasing graduate medical education transparency. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide an annual report to Congress and the National Health Care Workforce Commission on graduate medical education payments hospitals receive under Medicare. The report includes details on direct and indirect education payments, as well as the number of residents counted for payment purposes. The annual report to Congress and the National Health Care Workforce Commission includes details on graduate medical education payments hospitals receive under Medicare. This includes the number of residents counted for payment purposes, the percentage of payments made to hospitals for total education costs incurred. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to add a new section: "SEC. 9512. MEDICAL EDUCATION TRUST FUND." The Medical Education Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by appropriations and fees on health insurance and self-insured plans. No transfers are allowed after a certain limitation. The Medical Education Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States and funded by appropriations and fees on health insurance and self-insured plans. The Secretary of Health and Human Services serves as the trustee of the Trust Fund, and expenditures from the Trust Fund are available to the Secretary for making payments under sections without further appropriation. The Medical Education Trust Fund, funded by appropriations and fees on health insurance and self-insured plans, is overseen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary can use the Trust Fund to make payments under specific sections without needing additional appropriations. The net revenues are determined by the Secretary of the Treasury based on fees received and the decrease in taxes resulting from those fees. SEC. 6. PARTIAL FINANCING FOR TRUST FUND FROM FEES ON INSURED AND SELF-INSURED HEALTH PLANS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase fees on health plans for partial financing of the Medical Education Trust Fund.
